column1:
気楽 (kiraku) means easy or carefree.  
It is used to describe someone who has a relaxed or cheerful personality or something that does not require much effort or worry. 
To have a carefree or easygoing state of mind, without any worries or troubles or used to describe person’s mood or attitude. 
・気楽に生きる。Live easily. 
・気楽に話す。Talk carefree. 
・気楽な仕事を探す。Look for an easy job. 
・一人暮らしは気楽でいい。Living alone is nice and easy. 
・気楽にやっています。I am taking it easy.
楽 (raku) means easy, comfortable, enjoyable, simple or effortless.  
It is used to describe something that does not cause much trouble or difficulty, or that provides pleasure or satisfaction. 
It is often used to describe a task or situation.
・楽な仕事をする。Do an easy job.
・楽に暮らす。Live comfortably. 
・楽に勝つ。Winning with ease.
・楽しく過ごす。Spend enjoyably. 
・楽な椅子に座る。Sit in a comfortable chair.
快適 (kaiteki) means comfortable, pleasant, cozy or agreeable.  
It is used to describe something that has a good condition or quality or that makes one feel relaxed or satisfied.  
It is often used to describe a physical condition or environment and implies a high level of satisfaction or convenience. 
・快適な部屋に泊まる。Stay in a comfortable room.
・快適な気候である。Have a pleasant climate.
・快適な生活を送る。Live a comfortable life. 
・快適な空間を作る。Create a comfortable space. 
・快適に眠る。Sleep cozily. 
・快適に過ごせるホテル。Comfortable hotel to stay. 
気軽 (kigaru) means light-hearted, casual, easygoing, informal or easy.  
It is often used to describe a person’s manner or feeling. 
Often implies that one does not hesitate or feel burdened to do something. 
・気軽に話しかける。Talk to them casually. 
・気軽な気持ちで参加する。Participate with a light-heated feeling. 
・気軽にお越しください。Please feel free to visit us. 
・気軽に行く。Go casually. 
伸びやか (nobiyaka) means relaxed, free, unhurried, natural or unrestrained.  
It is used to describe someone who has a calm or cheerful personality or something that does not have any restriction or pressure. 
It is often used to describe a person’s movement, expression or state of one’s body or mind. 
・伸びやかに笑う。Laugh relaxedly. 
・伸びやかに歌う。Sing freely.
・伸びやかな生活を送る。Lead a free life. 
・伸びやかな気分で起きる。Waked up in a relaxed feeling.
・伸びやかな動きをする。Make a natural movement. 
・伸びやかな姿勢で話す。Talk with a natural posture..
のんびり (nonbiri) means leisurely, laid-back, relaxed, calm or unhurried.  
It is often used to describe a peaceful and carefree state of mind or an activity that is done without haste or pressure. 
It is often used to describe a person’s pace or style of living. 
・のんびりと本を読んでいる。I am reading a book leisurely. 
・のんびりと散歩する。Take a leisurely stroll. 
・のんびりした休日を過ごす。Spend a relaxing holiday. 
・のんびりとした性格の人 。A person with a laid-back personality.
◇ The difference in usage between these words is that 気楽 focuses more on the mental or emotional state of being easy or carefree. 
◇  While the other words focus more on the physical or external aspects of being comfortable or enjoyable.  
・彼は気楽に考えている。He thinks easily.
・彼は楽に考えている。He thinks lightly.
・彼は快適に考えている。He thinks comfortably.
・彼は伸びやかに考えている。He thinks freely.
・彼はのんびりと考えている。He thinks leisurely. 
◇ 気楽 and 気軽 both mean to have a relaxed state of mind but 気楽 focuses more on the absence of worries or troubles while 気軽 focuses more on the ease of action or behavior.
◇ 楽 and 快適 both mean to be comfortable or pleasant but 楽 has a broader range of meanings and can also imply easiness or enjoyment while 快適 has a more specific meaning and implies satisfaction or convenience.
◇ 伸びやか and のんびり both mean to be relaxed or natural but 伸びやか describes more of the physical or mental state of a person, while のんびり describes more of the pace or style of an activity. 
◇ 気楽 and 楽 are more subjective and emotional than 快適 and 伸びやか which are more objective and physical.
◇ 気楽 and 気軽 are more casual and informal than 楽 and 快適 which are more formal and polite.
◇ のんびり is more slow and calm than 伸びやか and 快適 which are more active and energetic.

いつまにか (itsumani ka) means before one knows or unnoticed.  
・It is used to express that something happened or changed without one’s awareness or attention, or that time passed quickly or unexpectedly.
・いつまにか眠ってしまった。I fell asleep before I knew it.
・いつまにか花が咲いていた。The flowers were blooming unnoticed.
・いつまにか夜になっていた。It became night before I knew it.
いつだったか (itsu datta ka) means when was it or some time ago.  
・It is used to ask or recall about the time or date of something that happened in the past, or to indicate that something happened a long time ago or vaguely.
・いつだったか、彼に会ったことがある。I met him some time ago.
・いつだったか忘れたけど、面白い話を聞いた。I forgot when it was, but I heard an interesting story.
・あの映画、いつだったか見たよね。We saw that movie, when was it?
いつのことか (itsu no koto ka) means when was it or what time.  
・It is used to ask or recall about the time or date of something that happened in the past, or to indicate that something happened a long time ago or vaguely.  
・It is similar to いつだったか, but it can also be used to ask about a specific event or situation.
・いつのことか、彼女にプロポーズした。I proposed to her some time ago.
・いつのことか教えてください。Please tell me when it was.
・あの事件はいつのことか覚えていますか。Do you remember what time that incident was?
いつか (itsuka) means someday or sometime.  
・It is used to express an indefinite or uncertain time in the future or past, or to indicate a hope or wish for something to happen.
・いつか日本に行きたい。I want to go to Japan someday.
・いつか君に会ったことがある。I have met you sometime before.
・いつか幸せになれると信じている。I believe that I will be happy someday.
いつの間に (itsu no mani) means before one knows or unnoticed.  
・It is used to express that something happened or changed without one’s awareness or attention, or that time passed quickly or unexpectedly.  
・It is similar to いつまにか, but it can also be followed by a particle such as か, に, or やら to add emphasis or nuance. For example:
・いつの間に寝てしまった。I fell asleep before I knew it.
・いつの間に雪が降っていた。It was snowing unnoticed.
・いつの間やら朝になっていた。It became morning before I knew it. 
いつの間に (itsu no mani) means when, when did or at what point.  
・Can also be used as a question to ask about the time or date of something that happened in the past, or to express one’s disbelief or astonishment at something that happened or changed.
・あなたはいつの間にこんなに大きくなったの？ When did you grow up so much?・This question shows that the speaker is amazed by how much the person has grown, and that they did not notice it before.
・いつの間に彼は結婚したの？ When did he get married?・This question shows that the speaker is curious or shocked by when he got married, and that they did not know about it before.
・いつの間にこんなに汚れたの？ How did it get so dirty?・This question shows that the speaker is puzzled or annoyed by how dirty something is, and that they did not see it before.

抽出する (chūshutsu suru) means extract or abstract.  
・To extract or abstract something from a source, such as a liquid, a substance or a piece of information. 
・石炭から液体燃料を抽出する。Extracting liquid fuel from coal. 
・データベースから必要な情報を抽出する。To extract the necessary information from the database. 
・コーヒー豆から香りと味を抽出する。To extract aroma and flavor from coffee beans. 
引き抜く (hikinuku) means extract or pull-out.  
・To pull out or extract something by force, such as a tooth, a nail or a plant. 
・虫歯を引き抜く。To pull out a decayed tooth. 
・釘をハンマーで引き抜く。To pull out a nail with a hammer. 
・庭から雑草を引き抜く。To pull out weeds from the garden. 
引き出す (hikidasu) means draw-out or pull-out.  
・To draw out or pull out something from a container, a drawer or a pocket. 
・引き出しからノートを引き出す。To draw out a notebook from a drawer. 
・彼女は財布からクレジットカードを引き出した。She drew out a credit card from her wallet. 
・机の引き出しからノートを引き出す。To draw out a notebook from a desk drawer. 
抜き出す (nukidasu) means draw-out or pull-out.  
・To pull out or draw out something from a group, a crowd or a pile. 
・人混みから彼を抜き出す。Pull him out of the crowd. 
・彼は名簿から自分の名前を抜き出した。He pulled out his name from the list. 
・この本は数多くの童話の中から傑作を抜き出して紹介している。This book introduces masterpieces drawn out from many fairy tales.
